This is work done with Mika Diamanti, @JJ_Fournier , Kenneth Harris and @MatteoCarandini Thanks to funding by @wellcometrust @SCglobalbrain  And I was inspired to treadify the paper after reading some lovely threads by @computingnature @MarinLab and @schneiderneuro (14/14)
Indeed at that moment when they licked in the wrong place, V1 and CA1 tended to wrongly represent the reward position, therefore, showing neural correlates of behavior (13/14) https://t.co/wEM9cSqVY6

We found that when the animal made a mistake, V1 and CA1 also made mistakes in a correlated way: they represented positions that were ahead or behind the actual position  when the animal licked too early or too late (12/14) https://t.co/EDztdrxSCl

Mice learnt to perform this task quite well but they weren’t perfect and made mistakes, either licking too “early” in the corridor, or too “late”. We wanted to know what's happening in the mouse’s brain when they made these mistakes (11/14) https://t.co/1d07sXOdxo

PART 2: These correlated mistakes were also correlated with the animal’s spatial decisions. We trained the mice to lick a water spout in a specific region of the environment  (10/14) https://t.co/GCWqjccDjC

What was interesting was that when the decoded position was wrong in one area, the other one tended to make the same mistake, suggesting that “V1 and CA1 indeed encoded the same spatial information” (9/14) https://t.co/ceBteaEeSF
Both areas represented the VR environment, and we could decode the position of the animal from the activity of V1 or CA1 neurons with good accuracy (8/14) https://t.co/dt4OyM1Y0X

Is the spatial position modulating V1 responses the same as the position encoded in the hippocampus? To test this, we recorded from V1 and CA1 region of the hippocampus simultaneously using electrodes (7/14) https://t.co/s9qQRbKOD6

We initially didn’t believe it. So, we tested every alternate factor that we (& all reviewers) could think of: spd, reward, eye movements, etc. All controls confirmed our initial observation: "Responses in V1 are modulated by spatial position" (6/14) https://t.co/EcAicNe9fK

Some V1 neurons responded as predicted: same visual image, same response. However, to our surprise, many other V1 neurons responded differently in the two visually-matching segments, suggesting a modulation of visual responses by spatial position (5/14) https://t.co/z4SWDBpx7T

PART 1: To have complete control of the features, we did this in virtual reality (VR). We designed a corridor which had  two visually matching segments, and recorded the activity of neurons in early visual cortex (V1)  while mice ran  in the environment (4/14) https://t.co/IFMEmllGzW

We designed an environment that can separate purely visual information from spatially modulated responses. The basic idea is simple: have the same visual image in different spatial locations, and observe the neural responses (3/14)

From what was known we expected a hierarchical system. Early visual areas would respond to just visual features while spatial information may appear in higher visual areas, as one gets closer to the hippocampus. A bit like an assembly line (2/14) https://t.co/hQA3EMkUFb

How does the brain process visual information during navigation? This is a question my co-authors and I set out to address in a recently published study in @nature Thread (1/14) https://t.co/I2AlwcIn5c https://t.co/LYtQdOI4gE
